supply_logistics.supply_status: Good for offensive operations. Short supply lines from Alexandria (250km). Division well-supplied with ammunition and fuel for El Alamein assault, though desert conditions strained water supplies.

tactical_doctrine.role: Assault infantry division specialized in breakthrough operations
special_capabilities: Highland fighting spirit and esprit de corps
tactical_innovations: Night assault with compass bearings (El Alamein 'Crumbling' phase)
Coordinated infantry-engineer-tank teams for minefield breaching
Use of bagpipes and Highland regimental traditions to boost morale
Insistence on Scottish identity and regimental pride ('Tartan Tam' leadership)
known_issues: First battle for reformed division - green troops with limited combat experience
Sustained ~2,000 casualties at El Alamein (11% of strength)
Infantry division lacking mobility compared to armoured formations
Dependence on attached armoured brigades for mobile operations
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Sun compasses, water discipline, dust protection, desert camouflage. Division arrived Egypt August 1942, had only 2 months desert acclimatization before El Alamein.

operations.name: Pursuit into Libya

historical_context.combat_effectiveness: Good - Division performed well in first battle at El Alamein despite being green troops. Major-General Wimberley's leadership and emphasis on Highland identity created strong esprit de corps. Night assault tactics effective. Casualties of ~2,000 (11% of strength) reflect aggressive operations.

validation.notes: Reformed 51st Highland Division (original surrendered at St. Valery 1940). Arrived Egypt August 1942, fought first battle at El Alamein October-November 1942. Major-General 'Tartan Tam' Wimberley insisted on Scottish-only personnel (except Middlesex MG battalion). Division wore Highland dress and tartans, used bagpipes for morale. Sustained ~2,000 casualties (11%) at El Alamein but achieved breakthrough objectives. Valentine tanks from 23rd Armoured Brigade attached for assault but not organic to division.
